case_title: MUHAMMAD AMIN IETC vs MIAN MUHAMMAD
complaint_summary: Mian Muhammad filed a suit seeking a declaration of ownership over land and invalidation of Mutation No. 33, alleging it was fictitious and void due to fraud and non-registration under Section 54 of the Transfer of Property Act.
investigation_summary: The plaintiff alleged that the defendants collusively got Mutation No. 33 sanctioned without his consent. The trial court initially dismissed the suit, but the appellate court allowed an amendment to the plaint, leading to further proceedings.

reasoning: Plaintiff acted fraudulently and came with unclean hands.
Sale was void under Section 54 of the Transfer of Property Act.
Equitable principles favored the defendants in possession.

legal_arguments: Section 54 of the Transfer of Property Act applies, rendering the oral sale void due to non-registration.
Relief under Section 42 of the Specific Relief Act is discretionary and was denied due to the plaintiff's fraudulent conduct.
Maxims such as 'he who seeks equity must do equity' and 'no man shall take advantage of his own wrong' were invoked.
assets: 200 Kanals of land in Square No. 42, Killas Nos. 1 to 25, Chak No. 67/4-R, Tehsil Fort Abbas, District Bahawalnagar.
sections: Section 54 of the Transfer of Property Act
Section 42 of the Specific Relief Act
key_issues: Validity of oral sale under Section 54 of the Transfer of Property Act.
Applicability of equitable relief under Section 42 of the Specific Relief Act.
Whether Mutation No. 33 dated 31-3-1955 was sanctioned fraudulently and is fictitious.
Whether the suit is within time.
Whether the plaintiff received full consideration under the alleged sale.

maxims.He who seeks equity must do equity: Relief denied due to plaintiff's fraudulent conduct.
maxims.In pari delicto, possession prevails: Possession remains with the defendants due to equitable considerations.

legal_terms.Mutation: A change or transfer of title in revenue records.
legal_terms.Equitable Relief: Relief granted at the discretion of the court based on fairness.

words_and_phrases.Oral Sale: A sale agreement not documented in writing.
words_and_phrases.Non-registration: Failure to register a transaction as required by law.

mutation_32.details: Proprietary rights conferred to Mian Muhammad for Square No. 42, Killas Nos. 1 to 25, measuring 200 Kanals.

mutation_33.details: Oral sale of the same land to defendant-appellants for Rs. 22,000.

plaintiff_claims: Mutation No. 33 is fictitious and void.
Sale is null and void under Section 54 of the Transfer of Property Act.
defendant_position: Asserted possession and validity of the sale.

legal_principles.principle: Section 54 of the Transfer of Property Act
legal_principles.application: Sale held void due to non-registration.

legal_principles.principle: Section 42 of the Specific Relief Act
legal_principles.application: Relief is discretionary and denied due to plaintiff's conduct.

details: He who seeks equity must do equity.
No man shall take advantage of his own wrong.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around the validity of an oral sale of land and the applicability of equitable relief. The plaintiff's fraudulent conduct and non-registration of the sale under Section 54 of the Transfer of Property Act were central to the court's decision to dismiss the suit.
